channel.title: Graphics card
channel.description:
I know I've created a thread like this a few months ago, but I'm finally to the point of where I'm getting fed up with my integrated graphics chip, so I'm ready to upgrade to a real graphics card, preferably a Nvidia product.
With that in mind, I was wondering if anyone could give me a few suggestions for selecting a card that meets these requirements:
[ul][li]$200-$300 (not too much over $300)[/li] [li]Has little to no problems with any game[/li] [li]Can record game-play while maintaining good performance (rather preferable)[/li][/ul]
If this may help, I play games like Diablo 3, Minecraft, World of Warcraft, and I'll possibly be trying out more games once I do finally upgrade to a graphics card. If anyone has a current setup that has treated them nicely, please do post your specs.

item.title: Graphics card
item.dc:creator: @chillwitm888 chillwitm888
item.description:
@chillwitm888 wrote:

[quote=“SilentCJ, post:13, topic:478469”][quote author=Tom link=topic=596694.msg4204300#msg4204300 date=1358684147]
I don’t know any of the other games he plays, and I don’t know what metro 2033 is.
[/quote]
One of the most graphically intensive games to date[/quote]
It is, but it is shitty as hell. Gameplay is terrible.
I think witcher 2 is even more graphic intensive.

Read full topic

item.title: Graphics card
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

[quote=“Tutorial, post:14, topic:478469”][quote author=SilentCJ link=topic=596694.msg4204307#msg4204307 date=1358685385]

I don’t know any of the other games he plays, and I don’t know what metro 2033 is.

One of the most graphically intensive games to date
[/quote]
I will not be playing graphically intensive games such as modern first person shooters.[/quote]
Aw well Diablo 3 is probably the most intensive from the games you listed, and it’ll run that a solid 60 fps no problem.

Read full topic

item.title: Graphics card
item.dc:creator: @Tom Tom
item.description:
@Tom wrote:

Nobody is using minecraft as a benchmark, he said he’ll be playing minecraft so I’m telling him what I get on minecraft. I don’t know any of the other games he plays, and I don’t know what metro 2033 is.

Read full topic

item.title: Graphics card
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

I don’t know why people are using minecraft as a benchmark, it’s really badly optimised.

On the topic though, a 660ti would be perfectly adequate for your needs, I have the GTX 680 and it’s brilliant, no problem with anything, although when I start using fraps with games like Metro 2033 it can still struggle.

Read full topic

item.title: Graphics card
item.dc:creator: @Tutorial Tutorial
item.description:
@Tutorial wrote:

I’ve been thinking about it and I’m finally deciding to up my price to $300. I noticed a lot of people really like the GTX 660ti, but I was wanting everyone else’s thought about this. If you know of anymore cards that are around the same price, please do tell.

Read full topic

item.title: Graphics card
item.dc:creator: @ziplock ziplock
item.description:
@ziplock wrote:

[quote=“Tutorial, post:8, topic:478469”][quote author=Tom link=topic=596694.msg4201324#msg4201324 date=1358235937]
Where are you getting these prices from?

PS If you’re going to pickup a solid GPU, you’re probably gonna want to upgrade your CPU as well. When I got my i5 it gave me at least 40 more frames on some games.
[/quote]
In all honesty, I think my CPU is fine for now.[/quote]

Yeah I have the same processor except it’s the Phenom, I think the only difference is mine has L3 cache. I also have a GTX 560ti and it runs games great. It’s a bit loud but I probably just need more cooling in my case. I had the Gtx 550ti before that but I sent it back as framerates would drop after 30 minutes of playing a game.

Read full topic

item.title: Graphics card
item.dc:creator: @Tutorial Tutorial
item.description:

[quote=“Tom, post:7, topic:478469”]Where are you getting these prices from?

PS If you’re going to pickup a solid GPU, you’re probably gonna want to upgrade your CPU as well. When I got my i5 it gave me at least 40 more frames on some games.[/quote]
In all honesty, I think my CPU is fine for now.

item.title: Graphics card
item.dc:creator: @chillwitm888 chillwitm888
item.description:
@chillwitm888 wrote:

radeon hd 7770 can run bf3 low on over 60 frames 130$
GTX 650ti will perform slightly higher with a few higher frames 150$
But I do suggest get the 2gb cards to future-proof it alittle
btw if you want a true gaming rig, spend atleast 250
gtx 660ti, 670, I hear 680 is only 400 right now
it got cheaper than when my friend brought earlier in october
if you plan getting 580… don’t
get 680

Read full topic

item.title: Graphics card
item.dc:creator: @Tom Tom
item.description:
@Tom wrote:

[quote=“Lin, post:4, topic:478469”]http://www.videocardbenchmark.net/high_end_gpus.html

You’re gonna have to fork up more than $150 if you want no problems with any game.[/quote]

Pretty much.

I currently run an overclocked HD 7750, it’s not a bad little card but there are much better ones. I paid ~140 dollars for it at the time. If you’re after an nvidia card a lot of my friends said the 560 Ti or even the 660Ti (Not that much more) are good choices but they cost a lot more than your budget iirc.

My setup is:

HD 7750 OCed
I5-3450 (4 Cores @ 3.10GHz with Turbo boost technology)

I get ~ 120 FPS on maxed everything on minecraft, the lowest it goes is probably 80 FPS and can play planetside2 on maxed (only just, though, especially in big battles). Not the best card, but has a good power consumption (I could run it on a 300W crappy PSU before I upgraded to my current 500W one) and gets me by.

I’ll be picking up a 660 Ti at some point, though

Read full topic

item.title: Graphics card
item.dc:creator: @Tutorial Tutorial
item.description:
@Tutorial wrote:

8GB RAM

AMD Athlon II X4 650 Processor 3.20 GHZ

Besides those base specs, I’m not really sure what other information you need.

Edit: I already know that I will need to upgrade my power supply.

Read full topic

item.title: Graphics card
item.dc:creator: @Tom Tom
item.description:
@Tom wrote:

Considering you have an integrated chipset I’ll assume you didn’t build your PC and that it’s from the shop or something, in which case it’d probably be a good idea to post your current system hardware to avoid any bottlenecking, or power issues with the new GPU. After you post that I’ll respond again.

Read full topic
